title: Football at the 2020 Summer Olympics – Men's team squads
text:
The <a href="Football%20at%20the%202020%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament">Men's Football Tournament at the 2020 Summer Olympics</a> was the international <a href="Association%20football">football</a> tournament in <a href="Japan">Japan</a> from 22 July to 7 August 2021. The sixteen participating national teams were required to submit squads of 18 players – of which two have to be goalkeepers – by 30 June 2021, 23 days prior to the opening match of the tournament. Additionally, teams could name a maximum of four alternate players, numbered from 19 to 22. The alternate list could contain at most three outfielders, as at least one slot was reserved for a goalkeeper. In the event that a player on the submitted squad list suffered an injury or illness, that player would have been able to be replaced by one of the players in the alternate list. Only players in these squads were planned to be eligible to take part in the tournament. On 2 July, <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a> confirmed that there was a change for the 2020 Olympics, allowing all 22 players named to be available on the roster, with 18 being named for each match. This change was implemented due to the challenges of the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>. The official squad lists were released by FIFA on 7 July 2021.
The age listed for each player is on 22 July 2021, the first day of the tournament. The numbers of caps and goals listed for each player do not include any matches played after the start of the tournament. The club listed is the club for which the player last played a competitive match prior to the tournament. The nationality for each club reflects the national association (not the league) to which the club is affiliated. A flag is included for coaches who are of a different nationality than their own national team.
Group A.
France.
<section begin=FRA /><a href="France%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">France</a>'s initial final squad was announced on 25 June 2021. However, after several clubs refused to release their players, a new squad was announced on 2 July 2021, along with additional players to complete the final roster. Before the start of the tournament, <a href="Niels%20Nkounkou">Niels Nkounkou</a> was called up to replace the injured <a href="J%C3%A9r%C3%A9my%20Gelin">Jérémy Gelin</a>.
Head coach: <a href="Sylvain%20Ripoll">Sylvain Ripoll</a>
Japan.
<section begin=JPN/><a href="Japan%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Japan</a>'s final squad was announced on 22 June 2021.
Head coach: <a href="Hajime%20Moriyasu">Hajime Moriyasu</a>
Mexico.
<section begin=MEX/><a href="Mexico%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Mexico</a>'s 22-man final squad was announced on 15 June 2021. On July 4th, <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Juan%20Mac%C3%ADas">José Juan Macías</a> withdrew due to injury and was replaced by <a href="Adri%C3%A1n%20Mora">Adrián Mora</a>.
Head coach: <a href="Jaime%20Lozano">Jaime Lozano</a>
South Africa.
<section begin=RSA /><a href="South%20Africa%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">South Africa</a>'s final squad was announced on 3 July 2021.
Head coach: <a href="David%20Notoane">David Notoane</a>
Group B.
Honduras.
<section begin=HON /><a href="Honduras%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Honduras</a>' final squad was announced on 2 July 2021.
Head coach: <a href="Miguel%20Falero">Miguel Falero</a>
New Zealand.
<section begin=NZL/><a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">New Zealand</a>'s 18-man squad was announced on 25 June 2021. As well as the reserves players named, <a href="Tim%20Payne%20%28footballer%29">Tim Payne</a> was named as a replacement in the event that <a href="Winston%20Reid">Winston Reid</a> doesn't receive a release to travel. On 2 July 2021, Reid was confirmed as available for selection. 
Head coach: <a href="Danny%20Hay">Danny Hay</a>
Romania.
<section begin=ROU/><a href="Romania%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Romania</a>'s initial 22-man squad was announced on 1 July 2021. On 9 July, <a href="Drago%C8%99%20Nedelcu">Dragoș Nedelcu</a>, who was set to complete a <a href="Loan%20%28sports%29">loan</a> move to <a href="Fortuna%20D%C3%BCsseldorf">Fortuna Düsseldorf</a>, withdrew from the squad at the request of the club and replaced by <a href="Ronaldo%20Deaconu">Ronaldo Deaconu</a>.
Head coach: <a href="Mirel%20R%C4%83doi">Mirel Rădoi</a>
South Korea.
<section begin=KOR/><a href="South%20Korea%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">South Korea</a>'s final squad was announced on 2 July 2021.
Head coach: <a href="Kim%20Hak-bum">Kim Hak-bum</a>
Group C.
Argentina.
<section begin=ARG/><a href="Argentina%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Argentina</a>'s final squad was announced on 1 July 2021.
Head coach: <a href="Fernando%20Batista">Fernando Batista</a>
Australia.
<section begin=AUS/><a href="Australia%20national%20under-23%20soccer%20team">Australia</a>'s squad was named on 29 June 2021. On 5 July 2021, it was announced that <a href="Marco%20Tilio">Marco Tilio</a> replaced <a href="Ramy%20Najjarine">Ramy Najjarine</a> and <a href="Jay%20Rich-Baghuelou">Jay Rich-Baghuelou</a> replaced <a href="Ruon%20Tongyik">Ruon Tongyik</a>.
Head coach: <a href="Graham%20Arnold">Graham Arnold</a>
Egypt.
<section begin=EGY/><a href="Egypt%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Egypt</a>'s 22-man final squad was announced on 2 July 2021.
Head coach: <a href="Shawky%20Gharieb">Shawky Gharieb</a>
Spain.
<section begin=ESP/><a href="Spain%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Spain</a>'s 60-man preliminary squad was announced on 5 June 2021. The 22-man squad was announced on 29 June 2021, with <a href="Iv%C3%A1n%20Villar">Iván Villar</a> replaced <a href="Alejandro%20Dom%C3%ADnguez%20Romero">Álex Domínguez</a> by an injury.
Head coach: <a href="Luis%20de%20la%20Fuente%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201961%29">Luis de la Fuente</a>
Group D.
Brazil.
<section begin=BRA/><a href="Brazil%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Brazil</a>'s 50-man preliminary squad was announced on 15 June 2021. The 18-man squad was announced on 17 June. However, after several clubs refused to release their players, a new squad was announced on 2 July 2021, along with four additional players to complete the final roster of 22. On 8 July, Ricardo Graça replaced <a href="Gabriel%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201997%29">Gabriel</a> who withdrew injured. On 14 July, Malcom replaced <a href="Douglas%20Augusto">Douglas Augusto</a> who withdrew injured.
Head coach: <a href="Andr%C3%A9%20Jardine">André Jardine</a>
Germany.
<section begin=GER/><a href="Germany%20Olympic%20football%20team">Germany</a>'s final squad was announced on 4 July 2021. <a href="Ragnar%20Ache">Ragnar Ache</a> and <a href="Keven%20Schlotterbeck">Keven Schlotterbeck</a> were nominated five days later, after <a href="Josha%20Vagnoman">Josha Vagnoman</a> and <a href="Niklas%20Dorsch">Niklas Dorsch</a> withdrew.
Head coach: <a href="Stefan%20Kuntz">Stefan Kuntz</a>
Ivory Coast.
<section begin=CIV /><a href="Ivory%20Coast%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Ivory Coast</a>'s final squad was announced on 3 July 2021.
Head coach: <a href="Soualiho%20Ha%C3%AFdara">Soualiho Haïdara</a>
Saudi Arabia.
<section begin=KSA/><a href="Saudi%20Arabia%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Saudi Arabia</a>'s 24-man preliminary squad was announced on 16 June 2021. The final squad was announced on 6 July 2021. <a href="Turki%20Al-Ammar">Turki Al-Ammar</a> withdrew injured and was replaced by <a href="Firas%20Al-Buraikan">Firas Al-Buraikan</a> on 21 July.
Head coach: <a href="Saad%20Al-Shehri">Saad Al-Shehri</a>
